conclusion: To determine the speed of the elevator at t = 60 seconds, analyze the acceleration-time graph.
The speed can be found by calculating the area under the acceleration-time graph.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s².
From t = 1 to t = 4 seconds, acceleration is constant at 2 m/s².
From t = 4 to t = 5 seconds, acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0.
From t = 5 to t = 55 seconds, acceleration is 0.
From t = 55 to t = 56 seconds, acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s².
From t = 56 to t = 59 seconds, acceleration is constant at -2 m/s².
From t = 59 to t = 60 seconds, acceleration increases linearly from -2 m/s² to 0.
Calculate area for segment 1 (0 to 1 second): Area = 1 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 2 (1 to 4 seconds): Area = 6 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 3 (4 to 5 seconds): Area = 1 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 4 (5 to 55 seconds): Area = 0.
Calculate area for segment 5 (55 to 56 seconds): Area = -1 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 6 (56 to 59 seconds): Area = -6 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 7 (59 to 60 seconds): Area = -1 m/s.
Sum the areas to find total change in velocity: Total change = 0 m/s.
Since the elevator starts from rest, final velocity at t = 60 seconds is 0 m/s.
